subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. If you
watched yesterday's "In Presence" segment,
I focused on a word, entelechy, and I
described it as your deep purpose, a
force driving you toward the realization
of your full potential. Now, I did a
little research on the word subsequently
and I realize maybe I emphasized purpose
more than actualization of your
potential, because the definitions that I
discovered, the dictionary definitions of
the word entelechy goes back to the
philosophy of Aristotle and it has to do
primarily with the idea that we all have
enormous potential.
Some of us fulfill that potential. We
become what we might become. I have the
feeling when I create these videos, for
example, that I am fulfilling my
potential right at this very second. But,
the word entelechy seems to imply the
quality that enables a person to
actually fulfill the potential and
that's a slightly different emphasis
than simply saying it's your deep
purpose. But let's talk about words for a
moment, words like deep purpose, profound.
I know I use those words a lot because
my intention in working with these video
monologues is to touch those of you who
are viewers at a deep level, at a
profound level. But what does that really
mean? I suppose one way to look at it is
to say that if those of you who are
watching somehow get into a groove where
you are actualizing your full potential
or at least a great deal of it that
would be deep because I suppose as we
look out at the world around us with
billions of people, how many people can
we say are achieving their full
potential?
Well, I don't know to be honest.
Honestly, I cannot say. I have heard
people say that some of the most
enlightened people they have ever met
are people who are very obscure. They're
not famous people. They're not well known
in the world. They don't have prominent
positions. They might work as caretakers
or as servants or janitors. They might
have low-level jobs and yet be extremely
enlightened in a deep sense, because
maybe what really matters is what's in
your heart, not what you do in the world.
On the other hand, maybe it all matters.
Now, another way of thinking about a
profound change is a change that you
take some risks for. I mean, for example,
those of you who are watching this
series because you respect the fact that
my main focus is parapsychology, that's
risky. We live in a culture in which
number one, your interest in the
paranormal alone is going to subject you
to a certain amount of scrutiny, a
certain amount of ridicule. A lot of
people will raise their eyebrows. They'll
think maybe you're gullible or that
you're becoming involved in a cult of
some sort or some kind of nonsense. So,
there is a risk there. There's also a
risk that it might actually be true.
You're risking your life and maybe
that's a good thing, to take a risk. Now,
on the other hand, why would you want to
take a risk with your life? It's your
life. You would want it to be as well
grounded as possible in the available
data, available information. I suppose
that may be a reason why you're
attracted to the material that I'm
offering because I am really endeavoring
to make it well grounded,
which means that there's an awful lot of
claims out there in the environment that
I'm not promoting and not supporting.
Sometimes because I'm simply ignorant of
them, they haven't yet come to my
attention. On other occasions because
I don't feel that they are well-grounded.
I could give you many, many examples
of people who are making claims in the
paranormal universe that I don't think
are particularly well grounded. Now, I may be
wrong about that and I imagine that
some of you would take issue with me
about what is and what is not well
grounded in this field. So, a profound
change might mean both risky and well
grounded, because let's face it, no matter
how much information you have, will you
ever have enough information to make a
completely rational decision? I don't
think so. I think there will always be
pieces of information that are missing.
I'll tell you something else, with
regard to the field of parapsychology,
there are a few very knowledgeable
people in the field of parapsychology,
parapsychologist themselves who have
conducted research, who have examined the
research very carefully, who remain
skeptical, who don't feel that the case
for psi has been adequately established.
I am not amongst those people. I have
had too many personal experiences to be
anywhere near that group. I think this
stuff is as real as can be. But, let me
explain it this way. My friend and mentor
Jean Houston has often used the phrase
"leaky margins." She says we have leaky
margins and by which
I think she means something along the
following lines. From the point of view
of mainstream Western culture, we live in
a rational universe and it's been
thought of as a rational universe ever
since the 18th century Age of
Enlightenment in Western culture. The
great philosophers of John Locke and so
on. We could go through the list: Bishop
Berkeley, Kant, Descartes, Spinoza - very,
very rational thinkers. It affected
our politics, it affected the growth of
science. There are many, many positive
things to be said about a rational
culture. But, the leaky margins that Jean
Houston refers to are the experiences
that never quite make it into the
mainstream. They're marginalized just as
parapsychology is marginalized, but it
points to a very different kind of world
than this picture of the rational
enlightenment. The challenge, of course, to
the rational enlightenment comes from
the postmodern philosophers, the
deconstruction of the enlightenment. But,
let's talk about what it means to be on
the margins for a minute, because here's
what I think about that. If we
were to go back just a few hundred years,
the whole field of electricity was on
the margins. We knew about lightning a
little bit, but until Benjamin Franklin
did his famous experiment with flying
the kite and attracting the
lightning and beginning to
develop an understanding of lightning in
terms of electricity, lightning was kind
of a marginal phenomenon. You know, we see
it. It’s real. It happens occasionally, but
there’s not much anybody can do about it
or use it in any practical way. And they
had other things. We knew about static
electricity, for example, but that was it.
We didn’t have a field of electronics at
all. I think it’s quite possible that
parapsychology today stands in a pretty
much parallel relationship to the
whole field of electricity and
electronics, going back just a few
hundred years. It was on the margins then
and then it became central to our
culture. The same thing could be true of
parapsychology. Or maybe, in a more
profound way, because parapsychology
reaches so deep into the nature of the
human soul, into the nature of the mind-
matter relationship, maybe these things
will always be on the margins.
Now, I’m getting wound up here and I know
I could go for another half hour at
least, pursuing this topic. But, I've
endeavored to keep these "In Presence"
segments short. The question is very deep
because it has to do with how much can
we really harness precognition and what
are the paradoxes involved in
precognition, for example? Does it mean
that the future already exists? And if so,
what does that say about us today? Do we
have any free will if our future has
already, in some level, happened? The
research on precognition, it’s kind
of marginal.
Philosophers will be arguing about it
for a long time. I guess all I can
leave you with right now are various
paradoxes to ponder. It's my hope
that in pondering these paradoxes, you
will find something profound within
yourself. So, let me leave you with just
this question. What does the word profound
mean to you? What would a profound change
in your life be like?
What would a profound change in your
life be like? Thank you for being with me.
